Table 1: Comparison with state-of-the-art methods on REAL275 dataset. Overall best results are in bold and the second best results are underlined.
P.E. Setting lists the input data type for pose estimation.
Since FS-Net uses different detection results under 3DIoU, we reimplement it as Ours(FS-Net).
Here Ours(FS-Net) inherits all loss terms of FS-Net but uses our pose decoder for fair comparison.

references:
Overall Performance on REAL275.
In Tab.Â 1, we compare GPV-Pose with state-of-the-art competitors on REAL275Â [47].
In line with our work, also DO-NetÂ [21] and FS-NetÂ [4] both use only depth observations for pose estimation, whereas all other methods rely on RGB-D data during pose inference.
Notice that we provide three variants of our method.
Ours(FS-Net) inherits the loss terms of FS-Net but uses our pose estimation network architecture and serves as the baseline for our method.
Ours(M) trains a separate model for each category, while Ours trains a single model for all categories.
From Tab.Â 1, it can be deduced that GPV-Pose achieves state-of-the-art performance w.r.t 5 out of total 7 metrics.
Specifically, for 3â€‹D503subscriptğ·503D_{50}, GPV-Pose outperforms the previous best method NOCS with 83.0 vs. 80.5. Furthermore, for the 5âˆ˜â€‹5â€‹câ€‹msuperscript55ğ‘ğ‘š5^{\circ}5cm metric, we surpass SGPAÂ [2] with 42.9 compared to 39.6, which increases by 3.33.33.3.
Interestingly, the best performance for 5âˆ˜â€‹5â€‹câ€‹msuperscript55ğ‘ğ‘š5^{\circ}5cm is achieved by Ours(M) with 44.2.
In terms of 5âˆ˜â€‹2â€‹câ€‹msuperscript52ğ‘ğ‘š5^{\circ}2cm, our method is inferior to SGPAÂ [2].
The main reason may be that SGPA employs a point cloud based shape prior, while we only rely on the mean size of each category as prior.
As for our baseline method Ours(FS-Net), we outperform it by a large margin w.r.t all metrics, clearly proving the effectiveness of our proposed contributions.
In Fig.Â 7, we additionally present a detailed per-category comparison of our method with DualPoseNetÂ [22].
As one can easily deduce, we outperform DualPoseNet by a large margin, especially when viewing the 3D rotation results for non-symmetrical objects such as camera.
Moreover, Fig.Â 5 presents a qualitative comparison with DualPoseNet on REAL275.
GPV-Pose is capable of predicting accurate rotation and translation estimations, even when the objects are only partially detected, as shown in Fig.Â 5 (a) camera,
while DualPoseNet tends to fail on such challenging cases.
In addition, to get a better grasp of our methodology, in Fig.Â 6, we demonstrate the bounding box voting results. It can be noted that the computed bounding box faces are accurate and the estimated confidence is reasonable (blue: low - yellow: high).
Due to space limitations, we present our results on CAMERA25 in the supplementary material. In general, similar to REAL275, we again achieve comparable or superior performance compared to the state-of-the-art.

As speed is a vital factor for many applications, in the last column of Tab.Â 1, we show the framerate of each method.
Regardless of the object detection time, our method can infer at a real-time speed >>50 FPS, and is thus very suitable for real applications with time requirements.
When using Yolo-V3Â [33] + ATSAÂ [55] to extract object instances, the whole pipeline runs at about 20 FPS, faster than most other methods.

id_table_2.caption:
Table 2: Ablation studies on different configurations of network architectures and loss terms on REAL275 datasets.
Conf. Rot. refers to confidence-aware rotation representation.
Without this term, we follow FS-Net to recover rotation matrix with SVD.
B.Box Voting refers to point-wise bounding box voting.
Symm. Recon. is symmetry-aware reconstruction.
Without this term, we directly reconstruct the input point cloud and â„’sâ€‹yâ€‹mBâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹csubscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğµğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘š\mathcal{L}^{Basic}_{sym} is replaced by â„’râ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹oâ€‹nBâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹c=Î»7â€‹Î¶â€‹(Pâ€²,P)subscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğµğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘›subscriptğœ†7ğœsuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²ğ‘ƒ\mathcal{L}^{Basic}_{recon}=\lambda_{7}\zeta(P^{\prime},P).
Overall best results are in bold.
references:
Effect of Geometric Terms.
In Tab.Â 2 (B) and (C), we evaluate the performance w.r.t. different configurations of network architectures and geometric loss terms.
First, we gradually add each loss term (from B1subscriptğµ1B_{1} to B4subscriptğµ4B_{4}) â„’(R)Bâ€‹B,â„’(t)Bâ€‹B,â„’(s)Bâ€‹Bsubscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğµğµğ‘…subscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğµğµğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğµğµğ‘ \mathcal{L}^{BB}_{(R)},\mathcal{L}^{BB}_{(t)},\mathcal{L}^{BB}_{(s)}, capturing the geometric relations between pose and the voted bounding box.
As can be observed, when adding these terms, the performance consistently improves from 60.4 to 63.2 referring to 3â€‹D753subscriptğ·753D_{75}, and 25.3 to 29.9 w.r.t 5âˆ˜â€‹2â€‹câ€‹msuperscript52ğ‘ğ‘š5^{\circ}2cm, which demonstrates the efficacy of the geometric consistencies.
Second, from C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} to C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} we evaluate the effectiveness of our loss terms â„’(R,t)Pâ€‹Csubscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğ‘ƒğ¶ğ‘…ğ‘¡\mathcal{L}^{PC}_{(R,t)} and â„’(s)Pâ€‹Csubscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğ‘ƒğ¶ğ‘ \mathcal{L}^{PC}_{(s)}, which are derived from the geometric relationship between pose and point cloud.
As before, the enforced consistency terms help again improve the estimatorâ€™s performance (i.e. we achieve an increase from 60.4 to 61.7 for 3â€‹D753subscriptğ·753D_{75}).

Effect of Confidence-Aware Rotation Prediction.
When incorporating confidence into the rotation prediction, from A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} to A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} in Tab.Â 2, the overall performance shows a significant leap forward from 52.0 to 56.9 referring to 3â€‹D753subscriptğ·753D_{75} and 19.9 to 22.7 for 5âˆ˜â€‹2â€‹câ€‹msuperscript52ğ‘ğ‘š5^{\circ}2cm.
As aforementioned, for several categories one rotation vector is much easier to predict than the other and thus enables higher accuracy.
Exemplary, for laptop, the average confidence for the rysubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¦r_{y} normal lies around 0.88, whereas the average confidence for rxsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¥r_{x} only amounts to 0.45.
Since rysubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¦r_{y} is typically perpendicular to the keyboard surface, it is a much easier target to estimate.
Therefore, exerting higher weight on rysubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¦r_{y} benefits the performance.

references:
Performance on Instance-level 6D Pose Estimation.
We also apply GPV-Pose to the instance-level 6D pose estimation scenario and compare with state-of-the-art instance-level and category-level methods.
As shown in Tab.Â 3, GPV-Pose achieves a comparable performance under the ADD(-S) metric (98.2% for GPV-Pose compared to 98.2% for DualPoseNet and 99.4% for PVN3DÂ [10]), whilst running almost in real time.
